definitions.definition: almost no; almost not; almost none

examples.text: There's **hardly any** tea left.
**Hardly anyone** has bothered to reply.
She **hardly ever** calls me *(= almost never)*.
We **hardly know** each other.
I had hardly seen my father since that day.
It **hardly seems** fair to put all the blame on him.
**Hardly a day goes by without** my thinking of her *(= I think of her almost every day)*.
At the time, I hardly spoke any French.
There was hardly a cloud in the sky.

definitions.definition: used especially after ‘can’ or ‘could’ and before the main verb, to emphasize that it is difficult to do something

examples.text: I can hardly keep my eyes open *(= I'm almost falling asleep)*.
I **could hardly believe** it when I read the letter.

definitions.definition: used to suggest that something is unlikely or unreasonable or that somebody is silly for saying or doing something

examples.text: He is hardly likely to admit he was wrong.
It's **hardly surprising** she was fired; she never did any work.
It's **hardly the time** to discuss it now.
You **can hardly** expect her to do it for free.
‘Couldn't you have just said no?’ ‘Well, hardly *(= of course not)*, she's my wife's sister.’
He’s 24—hardly a baby.

definitions.definition: used to say that something has just begun, happened, etc.

examples.text: We can't stop for coffee now, we've hardly started.
We had hardly sat down to supper when my phone rang.
Hardly had she spoken before she regretted it bitterly.
